content.description: An <math alttext="830 picofarads" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>830</mn> <mo> </mo> <mtext> pF</mtext> </math> parallel-plate capacitor has plates of length <math alttext="6.0 centimeters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>6.0</mn> <mo> </mo> <mtext> cm</mtext> </math> and width <math alttext="30 centimeters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>30</mn> <mo> </mo> <mtext> cm</mtext> </math>. The plates are <math alttext="0.92 millimeters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>0.92</mn> <mo> </mo> <mtext> mm</mtext> </math> apart, as shown. There is a plastic dielectric that fills the space between the plates.
content.question: The capacitor is connected to a battery and allowed to reach equilibrium. A charge of magnitude <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is on each of the capacitor’s plates. The same battery is then connected to a new capacitor with identical dimensions but with a dielectric that has three times the dielectric constant of the original. When equilibrium is reached, what is the magnitude of the charge on one plate of the new capacitor?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
